review.title: Modelling Protagonist Goals and Desires in First-Person Narrative
review.abstract: Many genres of natural language text are narratively structured, a testament to our predilection for organizing our experiences as narratives. There is broad consensus that understanding a narrative requires identifying and tracking the goals and desires of the characters and their narrative outcomes. However, to date, there has been limited work on computational models for this problem. We introduce a new dataset, DesireDB, which includes gold-standard labels for identifying statements of desire, textual evidence for desire fulfillment, and annotations for whether the stated desire is fulfilled given the evidence in the narrative context. We report experiments on tracking desire fulfillment using different methods, and show that LSTM Skip-Thought model achieves F-measure of 0.7 on our corpus.

sections.text: DesireDB aims to provide a test environment for modeling desires and goals in the personal narrative and predicting their fulfillment status. We develop a systematic method to identify desired and target states and then collect annotations to create gold-standard fulfillment status labels and text boxes marked as evidence.

sections.heading: 4 Modeling Desire Fulfillment
sections.text: We conducted a series of experiments to predict the fulfillment status of desires and goals, using different characteristics and models, including LSTM architectures that can encode the sequential structure of narratives. First, we describe our characteristics and models, then we present our characteristic analyses to investigate their significance for modeling fulfillment, and finally, we provide results from a direct comparison with previous work on the existing corpora.

sections.heading: 4.1 Features Description
sections.text: In our initial informal examination of DesireDB development data, we noted several ways in which an author can signal the fulfillment of a wish ("I was hoping to find a dictionary"). First, they can give a result that results in things going wrong. While we have found cases where authors explicitly say that their desire has not been fulfilled, we have many examples where evidence has been found that a condition for satisfaction has not been fulfilled ("The bookstore what went wrong.") True understanding of this type of narrative structure requires robust models of semantics (including negation) and knowledge of tasks such as buying books.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: We show that contextual characteristics help with classification, and that both previous and subsequent contexts are useful. Finally, we show that using the narrative structure is helpful, both directly in terms of the benefit of features of the discourse relationship and indirectly through the superior performance of a skip-think LSTM model. In future work, we plan to investigate richer features and models for semantic and discourse-based characteristics, as well as the benefit of more narrative-conscious characteristics. For example, the sentiment flow characteristics roughly pursue the notion that the arc of a narrative could implicitly reveal the resolution of a goal through changes in emotional states. We hope to investigate whether there are other harsh measures of change across the entire narrative that can improve the results.
